text:
DISCLOSURE

This tnvention celstes to an improved smoking product and a method
for its manufacture.

The geometry of the burning cone of smoking products currently
Produced leads to a reducing atmosphere in whicn pyrolysis reactions
Produce undesirable ingredients. This effect as created Dy the
restriction of the flow of air through or around the fused burning
mass, thus reduciny the amount of oxygen in the area kehind tre
burning cone which prohibits combustion of certain gases.

This invention cffere a method of manufacturing a smoking product
whose burning cone would not restrict the flow of air as much as a
conventional smoking product.

Smoking products that contain tobacco that has been snredded
finer than that found in conventional smoking products produce smoke
contalning lower amounts of the undesirable ingredients.

This effect is caused by the condensing and reburning cf smoke
on the increased surface area of the tobacco, thus more completely
Pyrolyzing the smoke to its more desirable ingredients.

The improved smoking product, to be described, produces less
undesirable ingredients by the increased air flow througn its
burning cone, or by incveasing the reburning of the condensed smoxe S

3
or both. °

Protocol for Enzyme Immunoassay of Nicotine
Introduction

As an alternative to RIA of nicotine, enzyme immunoassay (EIA)
is sought in order to avoid some of the disadvantagesof RIA currently
available, i.e. short seif-life of radivlabeled compound and ite
coat involved, potential radiation hazard, etc.

EIA could be as sensitive ae RIA and the sessy apeed covld be
equally fast and efficiest, Here,“described the development of an
enzyme immunoassay of nicotine using B-qalactosidase ag an enzyme
of choice.

Preparation of the enzyme labeled nicotine.

The compound which vill be used for the enzyme immunoassay will
be 6-p-aminobenzamido nicotine, The procedure for conjugation to
the maleimide coupling agent, meta-maleimidobenzoic acia (MMA), will

Cc be as follows,
A. Synthesis of nicotine ~ MBA conjugate,
1) Activation o€ cerboxy] group of MBA by thionyl! chloride.

text:
[ PROJECT TITLE: Tobacco Studies
J PROJECT LEADER: H. Lanzillotti
PERIOD COVERED: November, 1984
. 1. Low Nicotine and Control (J. Hearn)
| Objectives:
Identify mechanisms of nicotine delivery.
] Develop techniques for nicotine delivery control.
Investigate subjective effects of various sources of nicotine in cigarette smoke.
Status/Plans:
[ ~ Brazilian Tobaccos
Tobaccos fertilized with @ and 300 kg./hectare of KaSO, were prepared as
100% Air or Flue cured fillers and are being made into cigarettes. Tobacces
fertilized at 100 and 200 kg./nectare of K,SO, are being blenced (Air Cured
Flue Cured VA Stems) and made into cigarettes. Once all these cigarettes
j are received, they will be submitted for smoke anc chemical analyses.
Control of Nicotine Delivery
| Previously, casing Marlboro filler at a 10% target level with either glucose,
fructose or sucrose effected no change in nicotine delivery efficiencies. Recent
experiments indicate that an isosweet casing on a high alkaloid Burley tobacco
reduces the nicotine delivery efficiency by about 15%. The next experiment
will follow up on this latest information by casing high alkaloid Burley, DBC
Burley and DBC Bright tobaccos at 10% target levels of sugar to determine
| what the effects are on nicotine delivery efficiency.
Chemical Forms of Nicotine
| Literature references (dating 50-60 years ago) have been found relating to
the isolation of "bound" forms of nicotine from tobacco. As soon as copies
of these references are in hand, work will begin to duplicate the reported results
| 50 that the compounds can be isolated and structural determinations made.
N. Nonvolatile Components of Tobacco (R. Hale)
. is
| Objective: g a
Peal :
To separate, identify and subjectively evaluate nonvolatile components of Bright pm
and Burley tobacco. -

text:
FROJECT NUMBER: 6008
PROJECT TITLE: Computer Applications/General Support
PROJECT LEADER: G. D. Davis
PERIOD COVERED: March 1$ - April 19, 1988
Library Palantir/Pulcram Test
A. Objective: To develop a working understanding of the Palantic scanner
and the Fulcrum Fultext database; to create a Fultext collection for
user testing utilizing data captured through the Palantir scanner.
B. Regylt9: A total of 18 user specified files were entered into the
system using the Palantir Scanner. Two of these files were unable to be
scanned due to smearing of the newspaper print. All che files were
created from articles found in newspapers or magazines. Overall, the
Palantir did an excellent job of scanning this data in. It did prove to
be fairly time consuming though due to the Palantic user being a novice
and the data having been dexived from newspaper print.
Fulcrum was used to create a fultext database collection. It had no
apparent problems with any of the files referenced. The created
database and profile were brought to the Library. The necessary
environment variables and path names were added to the .logins to access
fultext. A cemonatration/training session was held with Charity
McDonald to introduce her to the basic commands, menus and terminology
neaded to use Fulcrum.
C. Gonglugions: The Library’s initial reaction to the fultext database
seemed very positive. They were particularly impressed with the general
flow of the menus and ease of use. It was determined that the Palantir
scanner could not be used to enter into the system data that was
generated before January of this year. Prior to this time the method of
storing data was an unconcernedly cut and paste procass that created
shadows, lines and severe skewing of the file making it impossible for
any scanner to read. However, due to improvements in this method used
to store data, the Palantic scanner will be used from this date on to
scan data into the system
D. Plans: To remain accessible to the library users as they continue to
test the Fulcrum database to answer questions or give support in anyway
needed. To continue expanding the current knowledge base about the
Fulcrum database and the Palantir scanner. A meeting with Fulcrum ig
scheduled for the week of May 9th here at CAD, At that time we will
have the opportunity to ask questions, tailer screens and develop fields
that will generically meet al) our user requirements. a

text:
DEVELOPMENT PROJECT SUMMARY FOR THE MONTH OF JANUARY, 1973
TITLE: Expanded Tobacco
OBJECTIVE:
Improved filling capacity.
DEVELOPMENT ACTIVITIES:
Complete Tobacco Blend "Stiffening" - Jetstream and ADT Dryers
Comparison runs with the closed loop ADT dryer and the
Jetstream unit showed a compacimeter filling power increase in
the range of 12-9% respectively when compared to regular ADT
dryer. Initial flavor group evaluation of finished cigarets
at both equal weight and a 7% weight reduction, show differences
primarily attributable to differences in cigaret delivery versus
the new drying operation. Cigarets designed to give equal
delivery versus control will be necessary to see if any real
subjective differences occur due to the processing step.
ADT Dryer Optimization
The experimental pilot plant ADT dryer setup is designed
to also examine air drying parameters as well as those of the
closed loop operation, First runs have begun with a goal of
determining relative drying contribution of this convective-
conductive type dryer.
Water Impregnation - Expansion
First attempts at moving the impregnation step from bench
scale equipment to small pilot scale units resulted ina
decrease of a significant portion of the expansion previously
seen (50 vs. 78 cc/l10 gms.). Subsequent studies show short
vacuum release time and minimum "clumping" of fibers are
required to obtain a high degree of expansion. Present
material from this study is in the 60-65 cc/10 gms. range
primarily due to accelerated vacuum release,

Pulmonary Reactive Uptake of Inhaled Toxic Contaminants
Pl: Edward M. Postlethwaie, Ph.D.
University of Texas Medical Branch
Pulmonary Division
The proposed project is designed to character{ze and compare across
species (including man) the kinetics of interaction and the predominant
substrates involved during the pulmonary airspace absorption of NO, and
0, with the goal of establishing a model for evaluating relative
dasimetry. The researchers will delineate the absorption determinants of
KO, and 0, within the intact, {solated lung, followed by the
determination of the extent to which uptake is localized to within the
epithelial lining fluid (ELF).

text:
ACS Release Of Preliminary Findings danencan
FEB 6 1986 On Cancer Prevention Study J ANCER,
RoA- PAGES Cancer  Society’s Cancer Prevention Study began int
September 1982 when 77,000 volunteers in every state, the District *
of Columbia and. Puerto Rico enrolled 1,200,000 persons in a long- f
term prospective study. The participants completed a four-page con- [
fidential questionnaire on habits, exposures, history of diseases, {
t etc, The plan was to have the volunteers report each year on the
fe vital status of each of the persons enrolled. For those reported
t dead, death certificates are obtained from state health departments,
“and analysis be cause of death made in relation to the replies on
the questionnaire.
N :
~The first follow-up began in September 1984 and is virtually complete.
Those Divisions of the Society that have completed their work have
traced more than 99% of the persons enrolled,
Even before deaths were reported we were able to make some analysis
ia relation to smoking. Smoking habits, among the subjects in the
study were compared to those of persons similar in age and socio- .
economic status who were enrolled in our first prospective study, €,f
~ces’' IT, in 1959, Massive changes were apparent. ta CPS JI, forty .
percent of the men had quit cigarette smoking, more than twice the *
eroportion who reported they had quit in the earlier study (seventeen
percent). Only twenty-six percent. of men were still smoking. Among
women, fewer had never smoked (fifty-six percent versus sixty-seven rey
percent) but fewer were current smokers (twenty-one percent versus
twenty-seven percent} and nearly four times as many had quit smoking
(twenty-two percent versus six percent). Further analysis shows
tremendous shifts on smoking toward lower tar/nicotine cigarettes,
Sixty-six percent of men and seventy-nine percent of women reported
they smoked cigarettes with «16 mg. tar. Men and women who smoked very
low/tar cigarettes tended to smoke more heavily but not enough to
compensate for the difference in tar content. We found no evidence,
as 1s sometimes alleged, that low/tar nicotine cigarette smokers
tend to inhale more deeply than those who smoke higher yield cagar-
ettes. .
It is difficult in most epidemiological studies of diet to relate
single food items to cancer mortality rates. The Cancer Prevention
Study II questionnaire asks for consumption per week of twenty-eight
different specific foods items, such as beef, pork, green leafy
vegetables, etc. We did a correlational analysis on these answers Piel
and found that they group into seven major categories: Vitamin-rich fo)
foods (vegetables, fruits, etc.); High-fat meats and eggs; Desserts; ret)
Breakfast foods (oatmeal, cold cereals, bran muffins, etc.); High- a
protein-low fat meats (fish, chicken, etc.}; Carbohydrates (white @
bread, rolls, potatoes, etc.); and butter and margarine. &
We found that some of these were highly correlated with other factors. .
Those who scored high in the vitamin-rich category tended to be better [x
educated, and also showed a negative relation to cigarette smoking. a
On the other hand, persons scoring high on the high-fat meat and '
eggs category were more poorly educated and tended to be cigarette
smokers, This points out the need to control carefully on smoking
habit and education when analyzing diet in relation to cancer, |
label: scientific_report

text:
, REPORT P 0500/3132 (INT) 890113 PAGE 1
1 SUMMARY
1.1 Cbjective
In the present 90-day nose-/head-only inhalation study on male
rats the influence of a filler ingredient on tha biological ac-
tivity of maingtream cigarette smoke was investigated.
For this purpose, the biological activity cf the cigarette KéDTEDL
(EDL), used as the reference, and tha test cigarettes X6D7EDM
(EDM) and X6D7EDN (EDN), both of which contained a different con-
centration of the ingredient, was compared with regard to the
following parameters:
(1} general condition and behavior of the rats,
(2) body weight,
(3) organ weights,
{4) gross pathology, .
(S) histopathology of the respiratory tract, and
(6) laryngeal epithelium thickness.
1.2 Experimental Conduct (a)
$6 male Sprague Dawley rats (strain Crl:CD(SD)BR, Charles River,
France), 6 weeks of age at the start of the inhalation period,
were allocated to 8 groups (12 rata per group): 1 lew- and 1 high- nu
<
sncke-dose group per cigarette type and 2 sham-exposed groups. So
rl
wo
Mainatream smoke (MS) was generated using modified 30-port »
Battelle Mark 3 smoking machines. Tha nominal total particulate 5
if)
ee lop)
(a) The experimental part of the study was performed by the TNO- »
CIVO Toxicology and Nutrition Institute, Zeist, Netherlands,
according to the protocol prepared by INBIFO and with the
technical asaietance of INBIFO.

This matunal appeass on the “List of Permitted Additives to Tobacco Products in the Unted Kingdom” with tha following maxwrunt

Cigarates‘Roil-Your-Own, 4A

spray dried Licorica powder tends to be more uniform in taste. For either type of Licorice, the glycymhiz content is tie crilical favor
factor relative to sweelness. Occasionally, either type of Licorice car have “scorched notes” and such batches shoukt be rejected

Date Received November 12, 1969.
Description Large cluaps of white, crystalline mater{al with an unpleasant odor.
Purity Assumed te be 100% active ingredient.
SUSUARY
'
The test materfal, a synthetic chemical, was evaluated for acute dermal
toxicity by a single, 24-hour dermal application to abraded and intact rabbit
skin at dosage levels of 1000, 2510, 6310, and 10,0C0 ng/kg of body weight. One
death occurred at the 10,000 ng/kg level; therefore, the acute dermal LD,, of the
test mater{al is estimated to be greater than 10,000 mg/kg of body weight. Signs
of dermal irritation included slight erythema, slight desquamation, and slight
edema. Irritation was generally comparable in intact and abraded animals.
PROCEDURE
A single, 24-hour dernal application was mide to the premoistened (tap 3
water) clipped intact (half the animals) and abraded (half che animals) abdominal &
